messages.content: Vote MARTIN GARNETT for a Stronger Opposition to a Hard Brexit.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: An alternative to a Hard Brexit
keyPolicies.policyDescription: An opportunity to vote to confirm or reject the deal negotiated to leave the European Union.
We will spend an extra £6 billion per year in our NHS and social care system paid for by a 1p rise in income tax.
A £7 billion investment in schools for equality of funding. We will deliver a broad curriculum and training in adult skills.

keyPolicies.policyTitle: A strong economy with investment in technology and all regions of the UK
keyPolicies.policyDescription: Investment in training for our future and economic policies for prosperity.

issues.brexitEurope: Fought in parliament to remain in the single market on which so much of our trade and so many of our jobs depend.
issues.economy: Investment in training for our future and economic policies for prosperity.
issues.education: Fairer school funding. A £7 billion investment in schools for equality of funding.
issues.health: Improved funding for the NHS. We will spend an extra £6 billion per year in our NHS and social care system paid for by a 1p rise in income tax. Healthcare spending.
issues.immigration: Britain cannot have unlimited immigration, but immigration has been unfairly blamed for many things. Fight for the world who desperately need help. Overseas students only stay for a short time and pay for their education.

community.content: Housing and Rentals: Protecting the rights of renters and landlords.

leaflet.personalStatement: Martin has lived in Erewash for 35 years and is standing for Parliament in Erewash for the sixth time. Martin is Chair of Governors at Friesland School in Sandiacre where he has served as a governor since 2002. Martin is an Associate Professor in Pharmacy at the University of Nottingham and has research interests in advanced nanotechnology, gene therapy and Healthcare. He has served as an advisor to EPSRC, one of the main UK Research Councils, on nanotechnology and Healthcare. Martin is keen to make the fruits of research work for the community in ways which will benefit us all.
